tr.td: Title:GMOS Spectroscopy of Cluster Galaxies 24 $\mu$m Sources
Co-I(s): Greg Rudnick, Vandana Desai, Dennis Zaritsky, Bianca Poggianti, Bo Milvang-Jensen

body.div: We have deep Spitzer/MIPS 24\micron \ observations for 17 galaxy clusters at $0.4 < z < 0.8$. Our cluster sample is drawn from the ESO Distant Cluster Survey, and not only spans an important range of velocity dispersions not represented in other surveys, but also benefits from a wealth of ancillary data. Because our MIPS imaging provides dust-obscured star-formation rates down to 2~$h_{70}^{-2}~\rm M_\odot~yr^{-1}$, we are in a position to significantly increase the census of star-forming galaxies in dense environments at $0.4 < z < 0.8$. However, to maximize the scientific return of the Spitzer data, we need to confirm cluster membership of the 24\micron \ sources. The available photometric redshifts, accurate to $\Delta z = \pm 0.1$, are too crude. We therefore request Gemini/GMOS-S time to complete spectroscopy for all $R< 23$ MIPS sources. Our spectroscopy is designed to detect [O~II] emission from star-forming cluster galaxies, and we expect to detect $35\pm 11$ cluster galaxies per field, yielding a total sample size of $600 \pm 200$ galaxies for the 17 clusters. Our immediate science goals include 1) a measurement of the cluster infrared luminosity function, for comparison with measurements made in both the coeval field and in local clusters, and 2) an investigation of the role of cluster 24\micron \ sources in the build up of the red sequence.
